Package org.fest.swing.fixture

The power and flexibility of FEST come from the fixtures in this package.

See:
          Description

Interface Summary
ItemGroupFixture<T extends Component> Understands simulation of user events on a Component that contains or displays a group of items, and verification of the state of such Component.
TextDisplayFixture<T extends Component> Understands verification of the state of a Component that displays text.
TextInputFixture<T extends Component> Understands simulation of user events on a Component that accepts text input from the user, and verification of the state of such Component.
 

Class Summary
ComponentFixture<T extends Component> Understands simulation of user events on a Component and verification of the state of such Component.
ContainerFixture<T extends Container> Understands lookup of Components contained in a Container.
DialogFixture Understands simulation of user events on a Dialog and verification of the state of such Dialog.
FrameFixture Understands simulation of user events on a Frame and verification of the state of such Frame.
JButtonFixture Understands simulation of user events on a JButton and verification of the state of such JButton.
JCheckBoxFixture Understands simulation of user events on a JCheckBox and verification of the state of such JCheckBox.
JComboBoxFixture Understands simulation of user events on a JComboBox and verification of the state of such JComboBox.
JFileChooserFixture Understands simulation of user events on a JFileChooser and verification of the state of such JFileChooser.
JLabelFixture Understands simulation of user events on a JLabel and verification of the state of such JLabel.
JListFixture Understands simulation of user events on a JList and verification of the state of such JList.
JMenuItemFixture Understands simulation of user events on a JMenuItem and verification of the state of such JMenuItem.
JOptionPaneFixture Understands simulation of user events on a JOptionPane and verification of the state of such JOptionPane.
JSliderFixture Understands simulation of user events on a JSlider and verification of the state of such JSlider.
JSpinnerFixture Understands simulation of user events on a JSpinner and verification of the state of such JSpinner.
JTabbedPaneFixture Understands simulation of user events on a JTabbedPane and verification of the state of such JTabbedPane.
JTableFixture Understands simulation of user events on a JTable and verification of the state of such JTable.
JTableFixture.Cell Understands a cell in a JTable.
JTextComponentFixture Understands simulation of user events on a JTextComponent and verification of the state of such JTextComponent.
JToolBarFixture Understands simulation of user events on a JToolBar and verification of the state of such JToolBar.
JTreeFixture Understands simulation of user events on a JTree and verification of the state of such JTree.
WindowFixture<T extends Window> Understands simulation of user events on a Window and verification of the state of such Window.
 

Enum Summary
JToolBarFixture.UnfloatConstraint Understands constraints used to unfloat a floating JToolBar.
 

Package org.fest.swing.fixture Description

The power and flexibility of FEST come from the fixtures in this package. Although you can use the RobotFixture directly, it is too low-level and requires, in our opinion, too much code. FEST fixtures can simplify creation and maintenance of functional GUI tests by:

  1. providing reliable lookup of GUI components (by component name or using custom criteria)
  2. simulating user events on GUI components
  3. providing assertion methods about the state of GUI components

The following example shows how easy is to use FEST fixtures. The test verifies that an error message is displayed if the user enters her username but forgets to enter her password. 


  private FrameFixture window;  

  @BeforeMethod public void setUp() {
    window = new FrameFixture(new LoginWindow());
    window.show();
  }

  @AfterMethod public void tearDown() {
    window.cleanUp();
  }
  
  @Test public void shouldCopyTextInLabelWhenClickingButton() {
    window.textBox("username").enterText("some.user");
    window.button("login").click();
    window.optionPane().requireErrorMessage().requireMessage("Please enter your password");    
  }

The test uses a FrameFixture to launch the GUI to test (LoginWindow) and find the GUI components in such window. This is the recommended way to use FEST. We could also use individual fixtures to simulate user events, but it would result in more code to write and maintain: 


  private RobotFixture robot;

  @BeforeMethod public void setUp() {
    robot = RobotFixture.robotWithNewAwtHierarchy();
    robot.showWindow(new LoginWindow());
  }

  @AfterMethod public void tearDown() {
    robot.cleanUp();
  }
  
  @Test public void shouldCopyTextInLabelWhenClickingButton() {
    new JTextComponentFixture(robot, "username").enterText("some.user");
    new JButtonFixture(robot, "login").click();
    new JOptionPaneFixture(robot).requireErrorMessage().requireMessage("Please enter your password");    
  }

Note: It is very important to clean up resources used by FEST (keyboard, mouse and opened windows) after each test; otherwise, the FEST robot will keep control of them and can make your computer pretty much unusable. To clean up resources call the method 'cleanUp' from RobotFixture, FrameFixture or DialogFixture.

Each fixture has the name of the GUI component it can control plus the word "Fixture" at the end. For example, JButtonFixture can simulate user events on JButtons.
